document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic review of the mygalomorph spider genus Linothele Karsch, 1879 (Araneae, Dipluridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic review of the mygalomorph spider genus Linothele Karsch, 1879 (Araneae, Dipluridae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Kolberger Strasse 12 F, 76139 Karlsruhe (Germany) bdrolshagen @ gmail. com
Swedish Museum of Natural History, Department of Zoology, Box 50007, 104 05 Stockholm (Sweden) christian. backstam @ nrm. se

bibRefCitation.author: Goloboff
bibRefCitation.refString: GOLOBOFF P. A. 1994. - Linothele cavicola, an new Diplurinae spider (Araneae, Dipluridae) from the caves in Ecuador. Journal of Arachnology 22: 70 - 72.

subSubSection.paragraph:
TYPE MATERIAL. —
Holotype . Ecuador
• ♀ ; Napo Prov. , Cuevas de Jumandi ;
2-3.II.1983
; A. & S. Roig leg.; MACN examined.
TYPE LOCALITY. — Cuevas de Jumandi, Ecuador .
DISTRIBUTION. — Only known from the type locality.

DIAGNOSIS. —
Linothele cavicola
“differs from other species in the genus by having very few teeth on the STC and strong ventral setae on the tarsi. Those characters, as well as the great elongation of the legs, spinnerets, and body, are possibly associated with the cave habitat. The eyes are well developed. The pigmentation is normal, although the spider (in alcohol) appears slightly less sclerotized than other diplurines.” Goloboff (1994) .

CT = 11. MC = 36-40. Colouration in alcohol: Overall reddish brown; maculae absent. Clypeus: narrow. Sternum, labium and maxillae:see Goloboff (1994 : fig.1). Leg formula:4123. Scopula divided. Preening-combs absent. Leg tarsi pseudo-segmented, see Goloboff (1994 : fig. 2). Spinnerets: apical segments of the PLS rigid. Spermatheca: consisting of two erect stalks bearing a single retrolateral vesicle in 1:3A, see Goloboff (1994 : fig. 3).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. — Comparison data for
Linothele Karsch, 1879 species.
Data is partly based on the first descriptions of respective specimens; if no ranges were given, the absolute figure is used here for max and min. Specimens within a species are sorted by their CL in decreasing order.Type material is marked with an asterisk.

subSubSection.paragraph:
According to Goloboff (1994) ,
L. cavicola
is known from a single cave system, where the spiders “[…] apparently do not make webs”, but “[…] were found walking on the ground, or walls of the cave […]”.
